I even felt kind of bad turning off my Mastodon instance, just because theyâ€™ve been so good this whole time. But I yearned for more, and Sharkey has the more Iâ€™m looking for.

That doesnâ€™t mean you should launch your own instance of alternative ActivityPub software, though! If youâ€™re new to this, and maybe donâ€™t know how to use a command line, or a terminal, absolutely get yourself some managed hosting.

While the muse for which I use to create has been a very slow monster, Iâ€™ve started to notice that ever since I basically rebuilt my life, I havenâ€™t really shared any of it that much. This is true for a lot of things I do, except for these scripts Iâ€™ve been making lately. So, letâ€™s fix that.

I already have an automated account on my Mastodon instance that I use for sharing random things cycled via Python scripts on my VPS, but what if we used it to share random songs from all of my releases?

And that, we have done.

Unfortunately, I canâ€™t use Bandcamp. Because Bandcamp wonâ€™t let you scrape artist pages with a script, and if youâ€™re going to use a browser in headless mode to achieve the same thing (and make it work), you need the server where youâ€™re running that script to actually allow you to do that.

entry.title: Is the Bluesky-Shine Wearing Off Already?

link.title: Is the Bluesky-Shine Wearing Off Already?

entry.content:
Like I do, Iâ€™ve been semi-tracking and participating in the boom of the Bluesky social network, even though itâ€™s not decentralized, currently, in any meaningful way. In my own experience, Iâ€™m having a hard time finding â€œmy people.â€ I donâ€™t even know if I have a â€œmy peopleâ€ anymore. But, that aside, from within my feed, Iâ€™m watching and seeing reports of constant troll attacks, some stating, â€œYeah, I donâ€™t like it here actually.â€ So, letâ€™s talk about Mastodon, again, maybe?

Over the past week or so, Iâ€™ve seen posts from people talking about, and have experienced personally, Kiwifarms trolls following people in some inane scare tactic. If you donâ€™t know what KF is, itâ€™s an extremely niche stalker website full of pyschopaths whose only hobbies are documenting and stalking people online, with mostly fabricated information.

Itâ€™s been giving people a bit of a sour taste in their mouths in regards to sticking to this, basically, brand new platform.

To add insult to injury, it seems now, as of today, that trolls are going around sending users extremely graphic and violent images of death.

I want to note, that Mastodon is not perfect by any stretch. But this is where true decentralization comes in, and saves the day.

If youâ€™re on a community run instance on Mastodon (or other AcitivityPub software), or your own, you donâ€™t have to put up with this kind of behavior. You donâ€™t have to play whack-a-mole with every new account that pops up. You can just â€¦ block out the instance that is acting as the source of this behavior.

Of course, Mastodon does have its own issues. There are a lot of basic FOSS guys, and do they love to either give you bad advice, unprompted advice, or scold you for doing things your way.

Iâ€™m showing you this, in order to be fully transparent about what you may encounter on Mastodon, and how we would deal with this. For context, I have Python scripts running on a VPS, and one of them sends random images from top posts across different subreddits, to Mastodon. Some of them are NSFW, some of them arenâ€™t. Either way, I also have it tagging each post with hashtags I wanted to have on it, like #python (because itâ€™s running on python!)

This isnâ€™t favorable to some. Simply using your mute button isnâ€™t enough. Some people have to tell you that they donâ€™t like that youâ€™re using your software, your instance, and your social media to do whatever you want, your own way.

And thatâ€™s fine!

We can send him into the ether, never to be heard from again. Or, we can block the entirety of the instance heâ€™s coming from.

In this example, Iâ€™m not sure what kind of behavior usually comes out of chaos.social, but we can check it to see if this is the attitude of more of its users, or if this guy is an outlier.

So, chaos.social looks pretty run-of-the-mill and likely not a massive source of basic FOSS guys trying to dictate to random people on the fediverse how they should post. We wonâ€™t have to block the whole entire instance. But! Since blocking single users is probably something everyoneâ€™s already familiar with, and doesnâ€™t take a lot to figure out how to do, let me just show you how one would block the whole instance, if in fact it was a bed of trolls and hats of the arse.

If you click that little pea-pod under a userâ€™s post, and look down, you can see the option to, as a singular user, block the entire domain.

What this will do, is evaporate all posts coming from that server, entirely. You will never see them again, unless you unblock them.

In the instance that a server happens to be a bed of trolls, maybe trolls who are sending people threats, being assholes, or generally gross, this is an awesome feature.

Now, I get it. The perfect social media experience would be never having to interact with, or deal with trolls, or people with a superiority complex. Unfortunately, thatâ€™s not the world we currently live in. When choosing a Mastodon server, or a server of any kind thatâ€™s connected to ActivityPub, it is very important to make sure that server has rules, and guidelines for behavior.

I understand that this is, for some, an incredible extra step to just signing up, and posting. But itâ€™s essential. It â€¦ will really help avoid situations down the line where youâ€™re suddenly asking the entire fediverse, â€œHey, why are there so many trolls???â€ and then everyoneâ€™s pointing to your instance, that has no rules.

If you decide Bluesky isnâ€™t the right place for you, donâ€™t go back to Twitter. Give the â€œLinux of social mediaâ€ a chance, and maybe you wonâ€™t be disappointed. Mileage may vary, but there really is something to using software that is highly customizable, near completely user owned, and run.

entry.title: Load Up the Gram, and Download It!

link.title: Load Up the Gram, and Download It!

entry.content:
Like an absolute madman, I slapped together a little Linux Python app for targeting an Instagram profile, and then downloading its entire contents. After much fussing with the unintuitive Github, and figuring out Twine, I uploaded it directly into the fully public system where anyone can download and use it. Thatâ€™s right.

Based on the â€œinstaloaderâ€ code, Iâ€™ve put a GUI around it, and made it really simple to use. Just input the username of the profile you want to download (such as your own, so you can leave Instagram!), select a directory, and then download! It may ask you to input a username and a password, which you can also input in the provided fields (I had to do this).

I donâ€™t condone using this to be malicious in any way, shape, or form. But I do condone using it to pull all of your data off of Instagram so that you can use it elsewhere. And â€¦ I guess, also back it up, away from the prying eyes of Mark Zuckerberg.

The source code is of course up on my github, but you donâ€™t even need that in order to install anything. For the first time, ever, you can mess with one of my projects by just using a mainline Linux / Python command.

Hoorah.

Itâ€™s constructed in a way that, while downloading, it randomly spaces downloads out between 1 to 5 seconds, in order to avoid rate-limiting. I tested the app on multiple random profiles and never got rate-limited even once. Although, like all things, Iâ€™m sure it could still happen.

But for now, I sleep.

Now, load up your terminal and type in this:

pip install gramload

entry.title: Digging Up the Distant Internet-Past
entry.content:
Like you do, I was digging around the WayBackMachine, trying desperately to recall the names of my old Geocities pages â€¦ much to no avail. But, there is one page I know the name of, that is at least partially archived, and I visit it every once in a while. Iâ€™m not sure Iâ€™ll share itâ€™s name because I made it when I was like 15 or so, and itâ€™s really anime-waifu, 2001 embarrassing. But, the sad part is, while the website was somehow archived, it wasnâ€™t fully crawled â€¦ except for a few things.

Most of the pages on this old site that I made in high school show nothing but blank white. But! I was â€¦ able to dig up the CSS font styling? I donâ€™t think I even made that. But the place was hosted on this service called Homestead. I think, at the time, it was some Geocities alternative. And then I found a pictures archive, from the website, and found this:

Of all of the things the WayBackMachine couldâ€™ve dug up â€¦ it somehow managed to save the avatar photo I was using on my little website, and on Animeboards.com.

Amazing.

Oh, and I was also able to access this:

Which must have been what I was using on the siteâ€™s sidebar. Itâ€™s not really anything all that special, but I can at least be like, â€œHey, I wrote the filename of this image and edited it in 2001, and in some miniscule way, thatâ€™s like reaching out and glimpsing past-me.â€

Could I do anything with this, now? Probably.

There we go, thatâ€™s marginally better. And I can tell by looking at it that I was using some kind of ancient photo editing software to manipulate it, and color out whatever was around her. I must have spent a while erasing that background. But, now, I can resurrect a piece of that old-internet work that I did, and add it to my modern website.

I may not be able to travel back to 2001 and stop myself from being so cringe at times, or give myself the chance to play The Sims when it was brand new again, or go on AOL Instant Messenger and talk to my two internet girlfriends one more time.

But, at least I got this?

No, but it is really a shame that crawlers didnâ€™t do a better job of preserving much less, lesser known sites. So much of my past, that exists that long ago are more like spots of cloudy memory at this point. I remember the house, I remember my computer, I remember the AOL dings. I remember the addiction to the forums, the hiding my screen in software dev class while I played DOOM.

Anyway, thanks for coming along for this kind of disappointing ride back to 2001.
